Dude, do NOT go into bioinformatics! It's a total mess!
@cannaroe1213   Please give more explanation and detail.

The TL;DR is that academia is going through a bit of a rough patch. The competition for funding is brutal, to the point that much of what is published is not true. This is throughout all of basic biology, and to a degree physics. If you go into bioinformatics, your job description will basically be to lie with statistics. To overlook all the fundamental errors, be it in the algorithms you won't have time to read, or the data structures, which you won't have time to properly learn.  If no one notices your lie, your boss will get all the credit for the paper, being the lab leader. If you do get caught, you are the sacrificial lamb.
@cannaroe1213   How about biotechnology?

@cannaroe1213   That more seems like an incentive, a field with so much to learn is not a problem. I feel I haven't asked you the two most important questions, what degrees and experience do you have? and where could I find reliable and credible information about what different fields are like?

​ @boglenight1551  PhD in Bioinformatics, Masters in Genomics, worked in top universities in the UK and Germany.  Unfortunately the issue is that academia itself is not currently credible. Many people in positions of power and privilege got there by being born rich, and they maintain their power by holding those that work for them back. Honestly, you just have to work and live all over the world, and only then will you believe it really is like this everywhere in Academia, and that this isn't simply the 8th bad apple in a row. You won't find these experiences written in any credible journals, because credible scientists don't talk about it. It would make them appear less credible. Never mind the reproducibility crisis, and all the people fired for bringing it up or proposing solutions.

@cannaroe1213   If you were to suggest a similar field for someone who's obsessed with biology and yet to do a bachelors, what would you suggest? I was already tied between zoology and biology, as I am obsessed with animal behaviour however I am also obsessed with molecular biology, I already have experience with computer science and love programming as well. I have considered veterinary science however I have substantial doubts about that as well.

Funny you mention computer as a job title.  Back in the day in artillery fire direction control the soldier or marine who operated the graphical firing table or GFT, (it's a type of slide rule used to figure out firing data for artillery) was know as the computer.  That job tittle is only mentioned in the manual gunnery publication and is not used in actual fire direction centers since its standard procedure to use actual computers.  The use of the GFT is still taught though.

The one original program was also based on Babbage's work, though Lovelace did find and fix a 'bug' in it. Jesse Ramsden was an early inventer working on mechanical computers. He had learned maths from his village priest, and became well-known for building various astronomical instruments of very high quality (though rarely delivered on time). He found a way to use long threaded rods, i.e. screws, to more easily calculate division problems. The problem in the late 1700s: screws were rare and usually handmade, and therefore irregularly threaded and too low quality to perform exact division.  So Jesse Ramsden invented a new type of screw-making machine, which could churn out long perfectly threaded screw rods. His division screws never really caught on. And yet, totally by accident, he helped invent the screw machine, popularize the modern fastener screw, and revolutionize construction and engineering.

Something I've felt missing from my primary education for awhile would be a bit of "historical computing". All though my education it was generally frowned to use calculators unless absolutely necessary. Rarely would you have a calculator on hand in the "real world" so you'd have to learn how to do these computations as best as possible with minimal tools.  While there were Blackberry devices around in my college years, the smartphone didn't come out until a year after I joined the workforce. Now everybody has a calculator, and so much more, on their person at all times. The access to computing power is only going to increase so much more over the next decade and it's hard to see what the tools of tomorrow will be.  This is why I view mathematics as less practical training for adulthood, and more of an exercise of your brain to train it to think through problems. I've never had any exercise in using an Abacus or a sliderule. Interestingly I do remember using square root tables (something apparently it was through I'd use in the "real world"). While I never will use them, I think it's a missing exercise in understanding basic mathematics.
